body: i agree, sounds almost like a bug though. however, i don't believe showing deleted files make sense if you can't restore them. only users who have create permission (and therefore can restore files) should see the deleted files in their trashbin.

generally i like the idea. however there are some corner cases which are not that easy to solve:

for single share files:

- the trash bin app would need to remember all recipients of the file to restore the share relation again if the file gets restored
- what do we do when a dir above the file was shared to other users or even groups? do we also remember this shares and recreate it explicitly again if a file gets restored? what happens to groups if members entered/leaved the group in between?

for files in a shared folder:

- what do we do if the folder no longer exists, the permission changed etc?
- if the folder was renamed should the trash bins also track this renames to be able to restore the files again for everyone?
- if the folder (and all folder above) get unshared or shared to additional users/groups do we also have to update all trash bins with the stored share relations? this operation can happen by various users (re-shares) and it is possible that the folders/files have different names for different users.
- additionally we would need to remember and restore the recipients of the given file like for single shared files.

that's just some thoughts. i'm sure we will find more corner cases if we think about it in more detail. this will become even more complex if server side file encryption is in place. because than we also have to remember all the share keys, maybe even update them etc.

i think the quite simple but easy to understand solution we have today is at least predicable:

- if a user deletes a file than he can restore it.
- if possible the file gets restored to the same location again (in case of a shared folder this means that all other people will have access to the file again), if not it gets restored to the users root folder.

of course i will not stop anyone if he wants to improve the trash bin with respect to shared files. but it is probably not that easy than it looks at the beginning.

i don't actually know how owncloud is programmed (and i don't have time to really look), so maybe it's not that easy.

but what if deleting a file/folder just become a "flag": the file is not actually deleted or moved, datas related to it in the database remains the same, we just add the information that it is supposed to be deleted?
theoretically, with this  method, a deleted file should behave just like a normal file.

therefore all the data are kept just like if it was a normal (shared or not) file, but in the file list, it only appears if the user decides to show the "deleted" files.

and of course we often check if some deleted files expired and should be actually deleted.

could this solve the problem?
any thought about this last idea?

generally a good idea. this would also avoid moving the files around and would save a lot of computation time. one drawback i see: what happens if a user uploads a file with the same name? than the hidden file would be overwritten. probably this could be solved when we rename the file before hiding it. this would also keep all share relations. but there is another problem: it would lead to a strange behaviour for users of external storages because the files wouldn't be deleted at all. this means the user would see all his deleted files again if he opens his external storage directly.

or at least it would be good to allow the owner of the shared folder to view all deleted files on it. 

this would allow "administration" control over team shared files by the folder owner. 

also it would be good to make possible to disable the option "delete permanently" as a security measure for team members.

"what happens if a user uploads a file with the same name?"
i guess it will append the same as when the file is not deleted.

regarding external devices, i guess we need to choose whether we want a correct sharing function or just a simple support of external devices.

as a user, currently i must say that the sharing and deleting function of owncloud is quite problematic regarding my intense usage of it, and far away from those of dropbox and google drive.
a few month ago, i chose to switch from dropbox to owncloud because it seemed to have nice advantages (keeping files on my own server, having the storage space i want, better managing of user accounts, calendar function, etc.).
but it actually seems that owncloud is based on a very nice concept but still have some very big issues to fix before being ready for a powerful use. i'm having big difficulties with the client software, with the sharing, the versionning and the deletion of files etc.

i must say that i love the concept of owncloud, but i'm using it for quite a while now and i'm now thinking of switching again for google drive because of all the problems i'm having with it. and i'm quite sad about it.

this is just my feedback as a user, even if i'm not sure it is the right place to say this.

@trobert94 thanks for your feedback, this is always very much appreciated!

> regarding external devices...

i talked about external storages, e.g. mounting your samba,ftp,dropbox,... into your owncloud. if you mount your dropbox into owncloud wouldn't you expect that deleted files are no longer in your dropbox once you access the dropbox directly? but than we can't just rename and hide the files.

> i'm having big difficulties with the client software, with the sharing, the versionning and the deletion of files etc.

i would love to hear more about the other issues you have. would be great if you could open separate bug reports for them!

> as a user, currently i must say that the sharing and deleting function of owncloud is quite problematic regarding my intense usage of it, and far away from those of dropbox and google drive.

we are working hard to create the best possible user experience. as said before, we are always interested in user feedback to learn what are the most missing features.

just a short note regarding the comparison between dropbox and google drive. we have to keep in mind that some stuff is much easier for them than it is for us. dropbox and google runs on their own server and they can decide which web server, database, storage, etc they use and than put their focus on it. on the other hand owncloud doesn't provide a single service but want to empower you to retain control over your data. but this means that owncloud need to work an various different set-ups (operating systems, databases, web servers,...) and support different storages like i tried to explain with respect to the trash bin issue. this shouldn't be an excuse, i completely agree that there is room for improvement. but we have to keep all owncloud components in mind and try to find a solution which works for all of them.
